segments.text: And that will interrupt us every once in a while.
This is August the 2nd.
We're in the MSC and I have the honor and pleasure of chatting with Mrs. Rachel Gonzalez about her memories of being a very proud and loyal Aggie wife and mother.
Say a sentence or two and let's chat.
Just to check this.
Yeah, I am a very proud Aggie mom and mother.
To begin with, please tell this machine to acquaint someone who might hear this or read it many years in the future.
Describe your family background, parents, where they grew up,
Well, my father came from Durango, Mexico.
He was educated in a Methodist school from pre-kinder all the way up through college.
He had a degree in public accounting, and he came to Texas in 1915 when he was run out of Mexico by Pancho Villa.
He came to and got acquainted with some people that knew Mr. Saurus Lucas who had a big ranch and owned a lot of land, owned the Berkley
and had a mercantile.
And my father, who was an accountant, got a job as the bank accountant and the manager of the Berclair Mercantile.
And that's where he met my mother, who was living in Berclair.

and her education was a private done at home by tutors because there was no public school in the motel and so my grandfather had tutors from Goliad come in and I would say she may have gone up to the eighth grade got an eighth grade education and that's where he she met my father they got married and
We had a family of 14.
They lived next door to my grandfather and grandmother.
What about your father's family?
Where did they come from?
My father's family was from Durango, Mexico.
They stayed in Durango.
Oh, so both your mother and father?
Were from Durango?
No.
Oh, I'm sorry.
My mother's all family were from Goliad.
Oh, I'm sorry.
My grandmother was born inside the mission, La Bahia Mission, and that's where she was baptized and had her confirmation, was married, and was buried from that mission.
How many generations had they lived there?
Do you know?
Oh, well, I guess all their...

by four or five generations because uh my grandmother originally the people all her people were from goliad around lava hill so they may be older your family may predate texas as a state that's on that side of the thing on my mother's side of the family grandmother's side of the family my father's family and when he came to the united states they remained in mexico
My grandmother, my father's mother, was a widow.
Her husband had died in their own minds, but
She doesn't know how she signed those mines over to a lawyer.
And, of course, she was well taken care of, and her children all were educated.

Like I said, they were educated in a Methodist missionary school, because these missionaries had come from England to Durango, established that school, and that's where my father got all his education.
And during Pancho Villa's time, he was an officer in the Mexican army, so then Pancho Villa captured him.
And my grandmother, knowing Panchavilla's mother, appealed to her.
And then one of my father's cousins, first cousin, joined Panchavilla's army because he had four sisters, just like my father had five sisters and he had four sisters.
And usually Panchavilla would come into a town and take, and the soldiers would take advantage of the women.
And so that way,
His cousin joined Panchayat's army so that- To protect the sisters.
To protect the sisters and the cousins.
But my dad was captured by Pancho Villa because he was in the Mexican Army.
And so through this cousin and through my grandmother's appeal to Pancho Villa, he told them that he would not execute him, but he had to get out of the country.
And that's when my daddy came to San Antonio, and eventually he wound up as a bookkeeper and accountant for Mr. Cyrus Lucas in Berclair.
Do you have any idea why he came to San Antonio instead of some other town?
Well, usually all those people that were being put out by Pancho Villa usually would end up in San Antonio.
And he was sitting in the hotel lobby of the Blue Bunny Hotel in San Antonio, and Mr. Lucas had room there when he would go do business with the banks in San Antonio.
And the man that had driven him there was his manager of one of the big ranches.
And he got to talking to my dad and asked my father, how do you know English so well?
And I told him and he said, well, you know, he said, we're here, we're looking for cowboys.
And my dad said, well, I can, I know how to ride a horse because he knew how to, says I can do that.
So that's when he told Mr. Lucas, well, I got you a ranch hand, a cowboy, and took him to the ranch.
And then the man realized that my dad didn't know how to cut cattle.
But in talking to him, my dad showed him all his credentials.
So he said, you know, Mr. Lucas is looking for a bookkeeper, and I'm going to tell him about you.
So he had an interview with Mr. Lucas, and he hired him.
And he worked for him until 19...
Well, after Mr. Lucas died, he kept with his son, Mr. Pryor Lucas, and then with his daughter, Mr. Lucas's daughter.
They too had big ranches, and he had all those accounts and everything.
So my dad stayed with that family as an accountant until 1948.
I think in 1945 he opened up his own accounting business in Beeville.
And of course he kept the Lucas's accounts, but he got more accounts like the drugstores in Beeville and several businesses and of course income tax time he... Now your parents met in...
In Beauclair.
In Beauclair.
And that's where they lived for a while.
We lived there until 1945.
1946 they moved to Beeville.
Did you start school in Beauclair?
We went to school, elementary school in Beauclair, and I, we didn't have a high school, I mean, there was a high school, but it was only for Anglos.
And the Mexican school was up to the seventh grade, and also the black school.

But there was no way we could go to high school, but my father would, my two older brothers, three older brothers would room and board in Beeville, and they went to high school there, and from there they came to A&M.
But I didn't know, my father didn't know what he was gonna do with me, because he didn't want me to room and board where I didn't know anybody.
But Mrs. R.A. Hall, whose husband was the superintendent of the Experiment Station, A&M Experiment and BUL, was a homemaking teacher and she had taught my brothers and knew my family.
So she said that she could keep me at her house and I could go to school with her.
And I lived with her four years.
I lived in their home four years while going to school.
Right now the, forgive me for this naivete, in Beeville there was only one high school?
No.
Oh, there was a separate?
Separate school.
For Hispanic?
For Hispanic, the Westside High School, and that's where my brothers graduated.
It was in my sophomore year of 1940, 1938, 39.
that we were integrated into the high school.
And I graduated from A.C. Jones High School in 1941.
About how many in your senior class?
Oh, I would say there were about 80.
And among your brothers and sisters, you're number what?
Number four.
You're number four.
Or the 14.
And growing up at home, did you all speak English or Spanish?
We spoke both English and Spanish.
And it was so funny because we did the studying.
The cooking was done in my grandmother's house because she lived next door.
And we did the studying there.
She had a great big old piano, almost as big as this, this grand piano that had this black big in the living room.
And we would get on top of that and we would study.
She had a table in the dining room and if our writing was not done right or she thought it was messy or something, she said, you made too many mistakes.
You have to do your work over again.
We didn't realize that she didn't know how to read English.
But just because of the writing and the messy paper, we had to do over again.
And she and my grandfather were very instrumental in helping my mother and father go to school.
As you were growing up, did you understand that girls were to be just as educated as boys?
Well, no, because a lot of my cousins
We were about the same age because my grandmother had an adopted daughter and then she had a daughter, my mother and another daughter.
And their children were kind of about the same age as we were.
But they, as soon as they got to the seventh grade, they didn't pursue anyway.
It was through my father that...
He said that we all had to be educated.
Well, that's what I was meaning.
In your family, with your parents, yes, you were going to be.
I mean, there was no, they said, well, we're going to quit or we're going to stop or we're not going to go to school.
That never did enter our mind because my father and mother were, and my grandmother and grandfather were very persistent that we went to school.
And do you remember which language you learned first?
Spanish.
Spanish first.
Spanish first.
Because I certainly don't detect an accent in your English.
Well, by the time we were going to school, we knew English.
And we could, you know, understand.
All right, so you graduate from high school in Beeville.
In Beeville.
And when do you start getting letters from this young man that's in the Air Force?

Well, I went on to college, San Antonio College, and I got a teaching certificate because he was doing the war, and they needed teachers, and they needed a teacher there in my little hometown, and my father said,
Well, you need to get a teaching certificate and come teach.
We need somebody to teach.
I was teaching the first and second grade, and then they went home at 3 o'clock, and then I taught social studies to the seventh grade.
This is in Berkeley.
In Berkeley.
And then a job came open at the Experiment Station for a secretary.
and he'd pay more.
So I went to, because I was helping with some of the family, because we had some in high school, some in college.
So I went to work at the Experiment Station, and that's when I got a letter from Ralph, which was like in 1944.
I think 44 or 43, I believe.
Because I went to the University of Mexico that summer, and I remember writing letters to all different, some of our hometown boys that were in the service.
And I know I was writing to Richard Bazan, who was stationed with Ralph.
And I was writing to, well, about four or five of the boys that were overseas that we knew, the families knew each other.
And so I was writing, I wrote Ralph a letter and told him all about me, and we just kept writing.
And when I came home from the University of Mexico, like I said, I was working at the Experiment Station, and that was in 45.
And I kept on writing to Ralph and the other people.
Well, the girls that he, because he was writing to five of the girls in BUL.
So Charlotte Murray and I kept writing to him, and we kept a race of who was going to be the last one, I mean, the first one to quit.
So I don't know why Charlotte put a write-in to him, but I kept on, you know, writing.
Did you all exchange pictures?
Yes.
Letters and pictures.
Letters and pictures.
And so when war was over in, well, I had visited with his mother before, during 1945, because he had been over there since 42.
and had not come home.
And I remember the first time I walked into her living room, the Christmas tree was up and it was like in April.
And she said, I've been keeping that Christmas tree because Ralph's been writing that he's been, will come home Christmas.
And he said in 44, he didn't come home.
And I'm hoping that this year he will come.
Well, then war with Germany was over and then the war with Japan.
And so he was coming home and he wrote and said that he would like to meet me.
So we didn't have transportation, but the Greyhound, I mean, we had a car, but we, I didn't, we just had only two cars.
My brother, oldest brother had a car and my father had a car.
So I rode the bus to San Antonio because I had an aunt that lived there.
And whenever we went to San Antonio, we stayed at her home.
So I wrote her and told her that this young man was picking me up and taking me to her house.

recognized me right away and of course let himself known and he took me to my aunt's house then he took me to his house his mother had prepared a meal and and no i think he took me to a cafe yeah that's the second time we went to sleep he took me to a cafe and we had dinner and i think we went to him we went to a movie and then he took me home to my aunt

And then the next day he picked me up and we went over to his house and that's when we had a Sunday dinner at his house and he took me back to my aunt and I picked up my things and my suitcase and he took me to the bus station and I went home.
And then he came to visit my family and the third time he came that's when he asked
Oh.
Now, what did your family think at first about your writing to these boys?
Well, my dad knew that because, you know, the mayor came to his office.
And he knew I was writing to all these boys because it was, you know, the thing to do.
Patriotic.
Yeah.
But he didn't, I mean, there was nothing.
We'd just write about what was happening in the family.
And, of course, David, it was David Alanis, and he was taken prisoner in Germany.
And, you know, the families just were close together.
Is there anything that you have teased him about since then that he didn't tell you about in advance?
Oh, I don't know.

what it be okay I don't I don't think I think he told everything and then his mother would great so now that's in the fall of 45 that's in October I think we he came home in October 45 is he discharged yes okay he's discharged and we got married in December right and what did you at that point
what did you think he was going to do professionally
Well, he had worked for Milam Chevrolet, and he had the job back.
I mean, that was the understanding when he went in the service that Mr. Freeman would give him the job back.
So he had a job with Mr. Freeman in the parts department, and we got married and went on our honeymoon, and when we got back, he went to work.
with Mr., at Milam Chevrolet.
And then in September, we got married in December.
September 29th, we had our son, and he kept working at Milam, but then Smith Motor Sales offered him a better job.
So he went to work in the parts department at Smith's as part salesman.
And we, that's when we bought our home.
What part of San Antonio?
In Palm Heights, what was called Palm Heights.
Had you quit teaching?
Yes.
I was a homemaker.
I was staying home with my son.
And so we bought the home in 1946.
And we furnished it, and we were doing pretty good.
Better than a lot of them, because my husband had a steady job.
But then my two brothers had graduated from A&M, and then Bert and Carlos were here.
And so he wanted to go on to school,
Carlos talked him into trying A&M, so we came up here to find out
what he needed and they told him he had to take the chemistry and the math in the summertime.
So that summer we got busy and we decided what we were going to sell, what furniture we were going to sell and what to keep.
Well, they let us know that we couldn't have housing at A&M that year.
So I was telling my parents and they said, well, stay with us the first year.
So we sold, we decided what furnish to sell and we sold the house and I think we sold it with a stove and a refrigerator.
And stove, refrigerator and the couch and the living room furniture.
We kept the dining room table and the chairs because that was kind of like an antique that I had gotten.
And we kept one bedroom, no, we kept the bedroom furniture.
And my brother in Berkeley had a vacant room in his home, so we put our bedroom furniture in there.
And the dining table, my mother kept it in her living room because it was a drop-leaf table.
She said, we can always use it because we had a long table in the dining room, but when we had more family, well, we could use it.
So I stayed with them a year and did substitute, and my sister was teaching in Berclair.
And so I did substitute in there for her and then for some of the other.
There were three, it was a three-teacher school.
And then he was able to get, he stayed at Bryan Air Force Base because it's freshman year.
All right, with that freshman year, when he came up here to enroll, did he bring the car?
Yes.
So you were without wheels.
No, no.
Yes, he brought the car, yeah.
That's right.
And the baby was three years old?

he was three well he yeah Ralph came the first of September and Robert was three on the 29th okay uh and you're living with your my parents your parents uh and uh so you were a stay-at-home mother well I did have my father in his office oh oh okay okay whenever he needed me uh he asked me would you know and how often did your husband come home
Well, he tried to come home every weekend, but then every other weekend.
Then he sold his car, and we were able to get another one.
He came home almost every other weekend.
And of course, holidays, we spent some time with his parents in San Antonio and the rest with my parents.
And then somehow, some holidays, he would work.
I mean, Miss Morisette was real good about giving him two weeks job, make extra money.
And we were able to make ends meet.
And of course, my parents helped a lot.
Then, the end of his freshman year, he found out that he had a place and they assigned us to Vet Village.
During that first year, do you remember any emergencies where you had to locate him by telephone?
No.
When I was in high school, I had Dr. Lancaster, who was a very young man doctor there.
And so after I got married, I kept going back to him.
And of course, when I got pregnant, he told me I had needed to find somebody in San Antonio for that.
But for checkups and everything, Ralph and I would go to him.
So when we started school and I took Robert, our son, for shots and things, he didn't charge me.
And so he said, just if you get sick, he gave us the name of a doctor.
His last name was Smith, Dr. Smith here.
And he says, go to him.
But we didn't have any emergencies that first.
No, I was thinking about while you were in San Antonio and he was up here.
Oh, no, in Beeville.
I was in Beeville.
Yeah, in Beeville.
Did you ever have to?
No.
Okay, because I thought he didn't have a telephone in his room.
And do you remember what Christmas was like that first year when he came home?
What did you all do to celebrate?
Well, we were at my parents' home, and we just did what we always have done because my parents always had all the kids.
And so we...

remember that my mother helped me with buying things for Robert and my grandmother who was had had a stroke when we just before we got married and my mother kept her in a hospital bed in fact they lived they built a bedroom and bathroom for her in Beeville and she was
Robert was very dear to her because it was not the first great grandchild, but she just fell.
And so we always celebrated Christmas with her.
And in that summer, before we came up here to Red Village, that's when she passed away.
And...
That was one of the saddest things because Robert was so used to her.
And it was the Fourth of July weekend and we were going to spend it in Beeville.
Robert Ralph had gotten a job with Smith Motor Sales in the parts for the summer.
And we were going to spend it in Beeville and she was waiting for him.
And finally she said, I just wish Robert would get, they would get here.
because she wanted to see him, but she died.
We were leaving San Antonio that evening, but she died about 2 o'clock.
I mean, she just had another.
All right.
And during that year when you were down there by yourself, I believe he said he sent you money?
Yes, out of his paycheck.
So what was your budget, your spending budget?
Well, he would send me, I think it was $60.
A month?
A month.
And I would give my mother, I insisted on paying and my mother wouldn't think about it, but I think I gave my mother $30.

And I kept 30 and out of that 30 we budgeted to buy, you know, clothes and if we had to, of course the drugstore, Daddy had to account for Joe and Joe was very good to us, the pharmacist, because he was a friend and he would always do discount on our medication or whatever we needed.
All right, and as you're getting ready to move into Vet Village,
Did y'all call it Vet, what did y'all call it?
Vet Village.
You called it Vet Village.
Did you have any choice or did they assign you to?
No, they assigned you, we were assigned a two-little bedroom and living area and kitchen.
Describe that apartment.
Well, it was just like this, maybe a little larger.
It was just a barracks that was divided in half, had a wall, and it had two bedrooms in the back.
Then he had a living room in an open place where they had a little dining table in the kitchen and a place for your washing machine.
It had deep sinks because you used your washing machine there.
It was a roll-type washing machine, and you used the sinks to rinse the clothes.
We moved there.
Of course, we had the two-bedroom furniture that we moved.

in we had the washing machine and it was furnished with a stove and refrigerator in the dining table and so uh we uh they had a kind of like a day bed but it what it was it was just a kind of like a cot with a wooden and it had a mattress and i fixed it to where it looked like a couch for the living room
I think we had a rocking chair that we brought from home and another little living room chair.
And we moved in.
When they assigned it, they wrote him and told him.
So we came up one weekend and cleaned it out.
I mean, did everything and put little curtains and got it all fixed up.
Then we moved the furniture before school started.
And when we got through finishing and school started, then the neighbors, Helen, Darren, and... D-A-R-R. D-A-R-I-E-N.
I believe we have it on there.
Okay.
And Lippincott.
I can't think of her first name.
And Francis Cantrell.
They were already there.
And Mary and Nance, they were already there.
And so they came in and welcomed us home.
And we would, in the evening, of course school started in

And we were getting the kids up like feeding them breakfast and getting them ready and they would go out and play and we'd clean the little place and we'd straighten it out and then in the evening we would sit outside on the grass across and we'd talk about the family and the kids would play and
We did washing and of course ironing.
The washing, we were, every time we wore, well we were assigned days to hang the clothes out because
I think four or five families used the same clothesline.
So there wasn't enough space for everybody.
No.
So you had to ask them if you had washing to do and you wanted to do it a certain day, you would ask them to trade with you.
So it was a lot of fun doing that.
And, of course, we joined the First Baptist Church as soon as we got in and joined WMU.
And we attended Sunday school.
And then Ralph was an usher.
